title: More Spotify subscribers is music to investors' ears
text:
Spotify's finance chief quit as the music firm revealed it had gained another five million subscribers in the three months to September, sending shares sharply higher.

Barry McCarthy will stand down as chief financial officer at the start of next year, after playing a key role in taking Spotify public in April last year.

The music streaming company now has a record 113m paying listeners. It posted an operating profit of €54m (£47m) for the quarter – only the second time Spotify has been in the black since floating in April 2018.

Revenue jumped 28pc to €1.73bn as the number of paying users rose by a better than expected 31pc compared with the same period last year.

Shares rose 14pc to $137.69 in New York, reversing some of the decline suffered since August following a difficult period for Spotify as US rivals seek to steal its business.

The firm told investors that its shares were a third below what analysts called their true value. It said: "Sometimes the stock price reflects the performance of the business and sometimes it doesn’t. But eventually, it always does."
